awd_titl_txt: III: Medium: Collaborative Research: Evaluating and Maximizing Fairness in Information Flow on Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Social networks (whom you know and whom you can reach) help determine access to hiring opportunities, education, and health information. They encode social capital based on network position, and in an era where access to information is crucial for advancement, this social capital can be immensely valuable. In this project, we study interventions on social networks that mitigate access inequality, that is, differences in access to information that emerge from where you are in the network. This project will develop novel mathematical and computational models to characterize how differences in position in a social network can amplify inequalities of access, and techniques to change the structure of the network that both increase the flow of information and reduce the overall inequities. Finally, the project will develop experimental methodology to assess the behavior of human agents in such online social networks to assess the validity of the designed interventions. The project will support the mentoring and training of underrepresented populations of undergraduate and graduate students, as well as the dissemination of the work through open-source software repositories and event organization at the top research venues in the field. 

We will develop mathematical and computational tools for the analysis of fairness in information access on networks. From there, we will characterize the algorithmic difficulty of mitigating information access gaps, develop efficient estimators to predict such gaps, and design intervention strategies to reduce these gaps. We will also consider how to characterize clusters of people who share similar access to information. More generally, we seek to connect the research on influence maximization to recent work on algorithmic fairness: the study of how automated procedures can perpetuate or exacerbate existing structural disadvantages of marginalized groups. The algorithms and results developed through these efforts will be evaluated using a combination of theoretical models, network repositories maintained by the PIs, real-world social network datasets, and experiments with volunteer participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this project were to (1) develop new computational methods for understanding how and to what extent network structure can drive differential access to information across a network, (2) develop new approaches to characterize variation in information access and to measure its improvement on a variety of networks, and (3) develop and evaluate new algorithms for equalizing access to information on networks under a broad variety of conditions.

This project created multiple new and scalable algorithms for automatically intervening in a network to equalize differences in information access, and created a new meta-learning algorithm that learns to automatically combine such individual algorithms in an efficient way, using only information about a particular network’s structure to do so. This project also developed (1) a new performance metric for reliably evaluating the efficacy of information access improvement algorithms and (2) a new structurally-diverse benchmark corpus of real-world networks that can be used to systematically evaluate these and other methods developed by the community. The performance of these new methods was systematically evaluated on the new benchmark corpus and compared in detail with existing state-of-the-art methods. Both the algorithms and benchmark data set created by this project were made publicly available as open source implementations for use by other researchers.

In addition, this project reshaped our understanding of (1) how to efficiently scale-up efforts to improve access to information on networks that spreads via pairwise interactions among individuals, e.g., information about employment opportunities or information relevant to public health, and (2) the role of network structure in shaping access to information. Past solutions to the information access problem had high computational costs that tended to limit their utility. This project developed multiple new and highly scalable algorithms that can closely approximate the accuracy of existing state-of-the-art methods at substantially lower computational cost. This advance extends the use of algorithmic approaches to improving information access to networks that are potentially hundreds of times larger than was previously possible. In addition, this project developed two new measures that help standardize the comparison of algorithms for improving information access on networks: (1) a new performance metric based on the average marginal improvement in information access per additional node seeded with the information, and (2) a low-dimensional measure of ‘spreadability’ of information on a particular network. The project’s systematic evaluation of new and existing algorithms for improving information access using the new benchmark corpus of networks, produced two important discoveries: (1) no single algorithm performs best across all different types and sizes of networks, implying that optimum performance comes from matching the particular assumptions of an algorithm to the particular structure of a given network, and (2) network structure plays a significant role in shaping the performance of all algorithms, implying that improving information access in a network requires understanding that network’s structural patterns. The project then created a new algorithm, using a sophisticated meta-learning approach that can leverage these insights to achieve a large (75x) speedup over the existing state-of-the-art, while achieving nearly equivalent performance across a wide variety of networks.

The results of this project significantly advanced our understanding of how best to design intervention strategies to improve information access in networks, while simultaneously substantially lowering the computational cost of applying those interventions, and they enable new investigations of other network-based intervention strategies to improve the fairness of network-mediated processes.
